qas.question: When did record companies first attempt to protect their CDs from copying?
Who said that protected CDs are not allowed to carry the CDDA logo?
Where does the Red Book mention copy protection?
When was the "anti-copy" subcode written in the Red Book?
Who created the anti-protection systems software?
When was the Compact Disc Digital Audio logo copyrighted?

plausible_answers.text: computer CD-ROM drives or some standalone CD players that use CD-ROM mechanisms

qas.question: What devices do standard CDs not play on?

plausible_answers.text: they violate the Red Book specifications

qas.question: Why does Philips want non-standard discs to have the trademarked logo?

context: The Red Book audio specification, except for a simple "anti-copy" statement <a2_0>in the subcode<a2_0/>, does not include any copy protection mechanism. Known at least as early as <a0_0><b3_0><b5_0>2001<b5_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/>, attempts were made by record companies to market "copy-protected" non-standard compact discs, which cannot be ripped, or copied, to hard drives or easily converted to MP3s. One major drawback to these copy-protected discs is that most will not play on either <b6_0>computer CD-ROM drives or some standalone CD players that use CD-ROM mechanisms<b6_0/>. <a1_0><b4_0>Philips<b4_0/><a1_0/> has stated that such discs are not permitted to bear the trademarked Compact Disc Digital Audio logo because <b7_0>they violate the Red Book specifications<b7_0/>. Numerous copy-protection systems have been countered by readily available, often free, software.
